item.title: Triads on different strings
item.author: rw@pobox.com (Rex Walters)
item.description: This is part 2 of a 2-part series on triads: Triad Introduction Triads on other strings (this page) Triads exist on more than just the top three strings, of course. The shapes change slightly on each different course of three strings because of the way the guitar is tuned. The best way to learn these additional shapes is using what Josh at Fretboard Anatomy calls “Octave Drop Chord Building.

item.title: Triads
item.author: rw@pobox.com (Rex Walters)
item.description: This is part 1 of a 2-part series on triads: Triad Introduction (this page) Triads on other strings Chords are just multiple notes played simultaneously. Technically, you can have two-note chords (AKA dyads) but most people consider three-note chords (called “triads”) to be the simplest possible place to start making real chord harmonies. Triads are formed by “stacking” intervals of a minor or major 3rd on top of each other.

item.title: Thoughts About Practice
item.author: rw@pobox.com (Rex Walters)
item.description: Nobody improves without practice, regular practice. But too many people (myself included) unconciously start to dread (and thus avoid) their practice sessions. I believe this happens for just two reasons: motivation and time.

item.title: What About Major?
item.author: rw@pobox.com (Rex Walters)
item.description: Hopefully our exploration into minor pentatonic scales wasn’t too exhaustive. We are going to speed up a bit as we delve into the major pentatonic scale. This isn’t because it’s any less important (far from it) but rather because all of the study methods we’ve already covered are equally applicable. It’s basically just rinse and repeat, but with a different set of five (or six) notes in a slightly different shape.

item.title: An Operator's Manual for Guitar
item.author: rw@pobox.com (Rex Walters)
item.description: This site’s conceit is to take an engineer’s approach to teaching the instrument. It attempts to be an “Operator’s Manual” for the guitar, written by an engineer for other engineers. Engineers can’t help themselves from asking “why” at every conceivable step of a learning process. Music is such a deep topic that it’s easy to get lost in the weeds doing this, but the only thing worse to an engineer than not getting an answer is getting a wrong one!
